CAT(1) General Commands Manual CAT(1)

NAME

cat — concatenate and print files

SYNOPSIS

cat [-AbeEnstTuv] [file ...]

DESCRIPTION

The cat utility reads files sequentially, writing their contents to the standard output. The file operands are processed in command-line order. If file is a single dash (‘-’) or absent, cat reads from the standard input.

The options are as follows:

-A
Equivalent to -vET.
-b
Number the non-blank output lines, starting at 1.
-e
Equivalent to -vE.
-E
Display non-printing characters (see the -v option), and display a dollar sign (‘$’) at the end of each line.
-n
Number the output lines, starting at 1.
-s
Squeeze multiple adjacent empty lines, causing the output to be single spaced.
-t
Equivalent to -vT.
-T
Display non-printing characters (see the -v option), and display tab characters as ‘^I’.
-u
The -u option is ignored for POSIX compatibility.
-v
Display non-printing characters so they are visible. Control characters print as ‘^X’ for control-X; the delete character (octal 0177) prints as ‘^?’. Non-ASCII characters (with the high bit set) are printed as ‘M-’ (for meta) followed by the character for the low 7 bits.

EXAMPLES

Print the contents of file1 to the standard output:

$ cat file1

Concatenate file1 and file2 to file3:

$ cat file1 file2 > file3

Number the lines of file1:

$ cat -n file1

EXIT STATUS

The cat utility exits 0 on success, and >0 if an error occurs.

SEE ALSO

head(1), less(1), more(1), pr(1), sh(1), tail(1), vis(1)

STANDARDS

The cat utility is compliant with the IEEE Std 1003.1-2008 (“POSIX.1”) specification.

August 2, 2025 macOS 15.6
